awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Variability, Impacts and Extremes of the ENSO-Asian Monsoon Relationship over the Common Era
awd_abstract_narration:
The research team aims to investigate the evolution of the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO)-monsoon relationship over the last 2,000 years, diagnose how various external forcings (e.g., solar irradiance and greenhouse gases) and internal climate feedbacks from the Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO) and the Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation (AMO) modulate the ENSO-monsoon relationship, examine whether the recent literature documenting ENSO-monsoon relationship changes over the instrumental period hold in the past, and generate a statistical forecast model of the Asian Summer Monsoon (ASM).
 
Both the ASM and ENSO are fundamental components of the climate system.  Investigating the variation of their relationship will deepen our understanding of teleconnections, air-sea interactions, and climate feedbacks. The paleoclimate data will serve as a testbed for the verification of current theories of the ASM thereby refining dynamical understanding.

The ASM supplies freshwater resources for nearly four billion people annually. Extreme events associated with the ASM cause and/or exacerbate floods and droughts, which have far-reaching social and economic impacts in developing countries.  Large model uncertainties, however, still exist in the model projections of the ASM.  The El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) is an important predictor of the ASM, yet the ENSO-monsoon relationship is not stable and exhibits substantial decadal variability.  The variation of the ENSO-monsoon relationship is likely modulated by external forcing such as greenhouse gases (GHGs) and solar irradiance but also heavily modulated by internal modes of climate variability such as the PDO and the AMO. Paleoclimate records can extend the temporal coverage afforded by the instrumental era and help address such uncertainty.

The potential Broader Impacts (B.I.) include integrating climate dynamics and modeling to refine projections of the ASM and its hydroclimate extremes, which impact the economic prosperity of nearly 4 billion people in Asian developing countries. The project will broaden diverse participation in climate modeling and climate risk research by supporting research opportunities for two assistant professors, a postdoctoral researcher, two doctoral graduate students, several undergraduate students including those from historically underrepresented groups, and outreach with K-12 students and the Girl Scouts of America.  Results from this project will be disseminated to relevant management agency stakeholders at the local, state, and federal levels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main goals of this project were to:

  1. Investigate the evolution of the ENSO-monsoon relationship over the last 2000 years.
  2. Diagnose how various external forcings (e.g., solar irradiance and greenhouse gases) and internal climate feedbacks (e.g., PDO and AMO) modulate the ENSO-monsoon relationship.
  3. Test whether the recent literature documenting ENSO-monsoon teleconnection changes over the instrumental period hold in the past.
  4. Generate a statistical forecast model of the ASM. The potential predictors consist of ENSO, Indian Ocean SST, PDO, AMO, solar irradiance, and GHGs. 

The main results of this project highlight the large magnitude of pre-instrumental variability in the teleconnection between the El Niño/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) and Asian summer monsoon (ASM) rainfall over the last millennium. In other words, even though observations over the instrumental era show that the ENSO-ASM relationship undergoes significant decadal-scale variability, we have uncovered even larger variability in this teleconnection across multi-decadal to centennial timescales over the last millennium using paleoclimate reconstructions and climate model output. This is important because current predictions and forecasts of both East Asian and South Asian components of the Asian Summer Monsoon rely heavily on ENSO (and tropical Pacific sea-surface temperatures) as a predictor of monsoon rainfall. Our results raise the possibility of additional challenges and uncertainty in predicting future ASM changes and extremes, as we have uncovered that the ENSO-ASM relationship undergoes changes via external forcing (solar irradiance and volcanoes) and via internal modes of variability (such as the Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation and the Pacific Decadal Oscillation) across multi-decadal–centennial timescales. Below is a summary of key results from publications emanating from this work thus far:

  1. Hu et al. 2023, Journal of Geophysical Research—Atmospheres: Tropical Pacific Modulation of the Asian Summer Monsoon over the Last Millennium in Paleoclimate Data Assimilation Reconstructions
    • We show that ENSO teleconnections to the Asian summer monsoon have evident decadal-to-centennial variability in the last 1,000 years
    • During most of the last millennium, El Niño tends to be associated with weak Asian summer monsoon rainfall anomalies.
    • Weak ENSO-East Asian summer monsoon teleconnection is associated with sea surface temperature anomalies resembling El Niño events.
  2. Du et al. 2023, Geophysical Research Letters: Solar Irradiance Modulates the Asian Summer Monsoon—ENSO Relationship Over the Last Millennium
    • We find that solar irradiance changes altered the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) and Asian summer monsoon relationship during the past millennium
    • Our work suggests that high solar irradiance weakens (strengthens) the ENSO-East Asian (South Asian) summer monsoon correlation
    • We propose that the mechanism of solar irradiance modulation of the ENSO-ASM teleconnection occurs via changes in the Western Pacific Subtropical High and ENSO event amplitude.
  3. Wang et al. 2024, Journal of Geophysical Research—Atmospheres: PDO and AMO Modulation of the ENSO–Asian Summer Monsoon Teleconnection During the Last Millennium
    • We find that the PDO impacts ASM variability more than the AMO, and its consideration yields improved Indian summer monsoon predictions over the last millennium.
    • We find strong non-stationary and variable impacts of PDO and AMO changes on the ENSO–ASM relationship across the last millennium
